Award.AwardTitle: Math Pathways & Pitfalls: Capturing What Works for Anytime Anyplace Professional Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers and developers at WestEd are developing, field-testing, and evaluating ten online professional development modules anchored in research-based teaching principles and achievement-boosting mathematics materials. The modules provide interactive learning opportunities featuring real classroom video demonstrations, simulations, and scaffolded implementation. The professional development module development builds on the Math Pathways and Pitfalls (MPP) instructional modules for middle school students developed with NSF support. The professional development provided through the use of these modules is web-based (rather than face-to-face), is provided in chunks during the school year and immediately applied in the classroom (rather than summer professional development and school year application), and explicitly models ways to apply key teaching principles to regular mathematics lessons (rather than expecting teachers to extract and apply principles spontaneously).

The project studies the impact of the modules on teaching practice with an experimental design that involves 20 treatment teachers and 20 control teachers. Data are gathered from teacher questionnaires, classroom observations, and post-observation interviews.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project staff developed, piloted and evaluated ten online, self-paced modules for professional learning about K-8 mathematics teaching. Module activities for teachers are anchored in research-based teaching principles and the NSF-supported Math Pathways & Pitfalls (MPP) instructional materials for K–8 students. The innovative online design allows teacher access in chunks (e.g., 2 hours/month) during the school year and immediate application in the classroom. Each module contains two cycles that illustrate target principles with video and activities where teachers plan, implement, and reflect on the use of a principle for MPP and regular mathematics lessons. In addition to these models of pathways to effective teaching, reviewers and teachers who field-tested the modules voiced the need for an opportunity to see and reflect on authentic teaching challenges. As a result, the project added supplemental resources for teacher exploration of instructional pitfalls. In these resources, teachers examine video of problematic use of MPP principles and see video clips that allow them to “sit in on” expert teacher focus groups discussing the teaching pitfalls.

Broader Impacts: The MPP online professional development modules offer districts and teachers cost-effective, just-in-time professional learning opportunities for the five pedagogical principles foundational to the MPP approach: Confronting Pitfalls, Making Sense, Building Mathematical Discussions, Capturing Key Ideas, and Visualizing & Connecting. Modules can be used flexibly: as part of a face-to-face experience or individually as teachers plan both MPP and non MPP lessons. Five of the ten modules focus on K-3 classrooms, and five on grades 4-7. Key ingredients in each module are videos of mathematics teaching and learning in authentic classrooms populated by children from diverse cultural and socio-economic backgrounds, guidance for managing classroom conversations about mathematics strategies and representations, and activities for applying the MPP principles to local curriculum.

Research Activities: Research during the project included an externally conducted usability study and a project-based pilot study. The usability study by Sutton Stern & Associates informed the second round of development, which included a revamping of materials due to the broad adoption of the Common Core State Standards. External evaluator Joan Heller conducted the pilot study in 13 classrooms. To gauge the impact of the online professional development experience on teachers’ practice outside of Math Pathways & Pitfalls lessons, six of the teachers also were observed in depth while doing “regular” math lessons. Research examined the level of implementation of the featured principle for a module along with teacher experiences of the MPP online modules. Data informing the work included in-module usage statistics, teacher surveys, classroom observations, and post-observation interviews with teachers. Results of the pilot study indicated that teachers enjoyed and learned from the MPP online modules. All 13 rated the experience as better than their average professional development experience (most were face-to-face), with 3 noting the modules were “among the best” of their professional learning experiences. Teachers remarked that the in-module classroom videos were valuable, “because they showed me what to expect from my students and what I could model as a teacher.” At the same time, teachers called for videos that show how things might go wrong. This result of the study led to the supplemental work that added “teaching pitfall” resources. Overall, the study found clear evidence of the MPP principles emerging in classrooms during teachers’ regular (non-MPP) math lessons. Teachers told researchers that MPP had changed their thinking about teaching. Prior to MPP, they were afraid to have students see, much less discuss, incorrect answers for fear that students would learn “wrong ideas.” However, teachers learned that well structured examination of carefully selected incorrect ideas can lead to students’ talking about, making sense of, and correcting their own thinking. Also noted from the study were two potential areas for future work: (1) create structures for teams of teachers to work their way through the online course together; (2) create new overview-units that take a step back from the lesson-level focus of the modules and provide for unit-level (multiple lesson) planning that supports teaching a combination of MPP and local math, integrated together, using the MPP principles and practices.

Dissemination: The video clips and slide shows included in each module are compelling in that they provide a vivid description of pedagogical implementation of mathematical discourse structures that effectively engage students, support deep mathematical understanding, and foster the use of mathematical language. As planned, the modules are a central part of professional development with the MPP intervention. The materials have been featured in many presentations to research and practitioner audiences. Also, video clips of lessons were featured in Jose Franco’s presentations on Student Voices at NCSM and TODOS conferences.  In addition, excerpts from each module’s Why is this Important? and Have You Wondered? segments figure prominently in the preparation of teachers for participating in the NSF-funded Using Math Pathways & Pitfalls to Develop Algebra Readiness project.
